comment_text: StarWolf watched this.
Be careful with your eyes.

Missed opportunity - at faster shutter times, the two "curtains" never expose the sensor fully (as happens here) but the second "curtain" already starts "closing" before the first "curtain" arrives at the other side.
Corollary, a speedlite firing would have helped to build an understanding of how this type of (time parallax) shutter works and what its limitations are.
This could also have illustrated that the speed of these "curtains" is constant at all exposure times - the exposure time being determined by how fast one comes after the other.

No shutter movement, it will just stay open. It's just like using "live view" or something similar. Shutter speed is probably just given because it's an effect that photographers understand, but the sensor will just start taking new information every "x" seconds, based on the shutter speed. This is why you can get jelly wobble on some sensors because it loads the top of the image at a different time to the bottom of the image, so things can shift around. They use "degrees" in cine cameras.

so there is no shutter movement in video ?.. I know about mirror it has to be locked .. but what about shutter ?
and if there is no shutter movement for video, then why we can control "Shutter speed" in video mode ??

So you can see through the viewfinder! You look through a prism, which then reflects light off the mirror and this enables you to look through the lens. It's one of the most interesting things about DSLRs - You can see a real world version of what you're shooting. The mirror will also bounce light for the focusing points as well, so you get autofocus. In mirrorless cameras, I think there's a semi-transparent layer which does this and you use an electronic viewfinder (which processes the image)
With a DSLR in video mode, it will just hold the mirror up and expose the sensor. It won't keep flickering back and fro like it does for photos.
Mirror projects light to optical viewfinder to see the image/compose image before taking the picture ....  :)

My good friend and I have rented Phantom cameras a few times. They are amazing, but generally cost as much as a small to mid sized house depending on the version you need. Which is why most people rent them instead of buy them. The Phantom MIRO cameras are revolutionary in that the entry level models are less than half the price of the previous entry models and are 100% self contained and run on Sony batteries. Prior to MIRO, you could expect to spend no less than $100k on self contained units.

You measure exposure time from the moment the curtain starts to open (the curtain is the little thing that moves after the mirror is lifted) till when the 2nd curtain completely closes the sensor. By looking at the video we see that the time from these 2 events is roughly 33 ms. Cameras usually display exposure times in term of fraction of a second, so the exporsure time here is probably 1/30 (that is, 1/30 s = ~0.0333 ms).

@fuenffuenf  Yeah, Phantom cameras shoot at sever gigabytes per second. Essentially, you only have enough space on a 12gb built in memory to store maybe 4 seconds of 1000FPS footage. Thus, every time you get a shot you want to keep, you have to output it to external storage. The easiest ways are to their proprietary cinemag hard drives, or to laptops directly. Being as cinemag storage costs several thousand dollars for basic models, laptops are the most cost efficient option.

@Fuzzyfull Move upwards after the other covers move back into place maybe? I'm sure there'd be downtime for it to reset, or as you say the two covers could move in the opposite manner to how they did :)

In DSLRs with live previews going to an LCD then the sensor is always exposed and a slightly more elaborate process of pre-covering, then exposing and covering for the shot, then post-exposing so the live preview can be restarted is required.

@Fuzzyfull Of course the resetting is done in such an order that there is always one curtain blocking the light falling on the sensor. The first curtain is moved upwards again first, followed by the second.

@Fuzzyfull Nope, the shutter is reset again after the exposure. you can't see that because the mirror flipping up is blocking the view. If you take an old slr with manual film transport and open it up, take the film out you can see exactly what's happening when winding the film forward. This action also resets the shutter and its curtains in the original position. The shutter, even in today's world still uses mechanical things like springs and levers which only work in one way.
Does the same thing happen to a black and white camera?
Cool, I just started learning about cameras and how they take images at school today...

@teundilles 
An old lens that's totally manual.
Is that an old nikon lens on the high speed camera to shoot the canonshutter? from the looks of it, I would say it's a nikkor 50mm 1.4 ais?
@DeltaRC1262 LOL.

@Fuzzyfull If the shutter would come up from the bottom, that would mean an uneven light across the sensor. The top part would have received more light than the lower part. This would be especially noticable when using faster shutterspeeds. In fact, starting from 1/500 (depending on the camera), the top part starts moving down before the lower parts has reached the bottom. Each of these two parts moving over the sensor are called 'curtains'.
that's awesome! :D wobble-wobble shutter :D
I would say something like 1/30 s. Congrats on your baby.
@Fuzzyfull There are two curtains, this is needed so you can have different exposures. Some exposure settings both curtains will be in front of the sensor at the same time.
